title: fNIRS in the Neurodevelopment of Cognition
text:
The rationale behind fNIRS


Some materials have different optical properties than others (e.g., they absorbe more light of some colors)



https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:EM_spectrumrevised.png

title: fNIRS in the Neurodevelopment of Cognition
text:
The rationale behind fNIRS


We can study the composition of an object by analysing how light behaves when passing through it (i.g., spectroscopy)

title: fNIRS in the Neurodevelopment of Cognition
text:
The rationale behind fNIRS


Oxy-haemoglobin (HbO) and deoxy-haemoglobin (HbR) have absorb near-infrared light differently




Figure 1: Optical absorption of haemoglobin.

title: fNIRS in the Neurodevelopment of Cognition
text:
The rationale behind fNIRS


If we shine near-infrared light into biological tissue, we can estimate changes in relative concentration of HbO and HbR time (functional)


Modified Beer-Lambert law:
\[
\Delta A(\lambda_1) = \text{DPF} \cdot r \cdot [\epsilon_{\text{HbO}} (\lambda_1) \cdot \Delta c_{\text{HbO}} + \epsilon_{\text{HbR}}(\lambda_1) \cdot \Delta c_{\text{HbR}}]
\qquad(1)\]
\[
\Delta A(\lambda_2) = \text{DPF} \cdot r \cdot [\epsilon_{\text{HbO}} (\lambda_2) \cdot \Delta c_{\text{HbO}} + \epsilon_{\text{HbR}}(\lambda_2) \cdot \Delta c_{\text{HbR}}]
\qquad(2)\]

\(\text{DPF}\): differential pathlength factor
\(\epsilon_{\text{HbO, HbR}}\): molar decadic absorption coefficient
\(\Delta c_{\text{HbO, HbR}}\): concentration change in HbO or HbR.

title: fNIRS in the Neurodevelopment of Cognition
text:
The rationale behind fNIRS


In brain tissue, neuronal activity is followed by BOLD response. Using fNIRS, we can measure BOLD signal as a proxy of brain activity in an area.



Cinciute (2019), PeerJ. https://doi.org/10.7717/peerj.6621

title: fNIRS in the Neurodevelopment of Cognition
text:
Desiging fNIRS experiments

Low temporal resolution: the BOLD response takes time! (~15 seconds)
Two main types of experimental designs


Arco et al. (2018)

title: fNIRS in the Neurodevelopment of Cognition
text:
Desiging fNIRS experiments
Working with the youngest

No instructions
Plenty of movement
Short attention and memory span

title: fNIRS in the Neurodevelopment of Cognition
text:
Data acquisition
Commercially available sytems
Society for functional Near Infreared spectroscopy (https://fnirs.org)

NIRx (Germany): NIRSport2
Artinis (The Netherlands): Brite, OxyMon
Hitachi (Japan): ETG 4000
GowerLabs (UK): LUMO (HD-DOT system)
Cortivision (Poland): Spectrum C23 fNIRS
PIONIRS (Italy): NIRSBOX

title: fNIRS in the Neurodevelopment of Cognition
text:
Sofware

Homer2, Homer3 (Huppert et al. 2009)
MNE-Python (Gramfort et al. 2013), MNE-NIRS (Luke et al. 2021)
AnalyzIR (Santosa et al. 2018)
Brainstorm (Tadel et al. 2011), NIRStorm (Delaire et al. 2025)

title: fNIRS in the Neurodevelopment of Cognition
text:
Data preprocessing

Import raw light intensity data (e.g., .snirf)
Transform for optical density data
Signal quality checks and enhancement: 3.1) Scalp coupling index 3.2) Short channel regression 3.3) Motion arctifact correction (e.g., temporal derivative distribution repair)
Transform to \(\Delta\text{HbO}\) and \(\Delta\text{HbR}\)
Attenuate physiological arctifacts (e.g., band-pass filtering)
Epoching and averaging

title: fNIRS in the Neurodevelopment of Cognition
text:
Data preprocessing and analysis
Steps

Many choices to be made: Which steps? In what order?
Always consider your research question, your population of interest, and your device!
Many different pipelines generate equivalent results (Yücel et al. 2024)
Today, we are following recommendations by Gemignani and Gervain (2021)

text:
References




Abboub, Nawal, Thierry Nazzi, and Judit Gervain. 2016. “Prosodic Grouping at Birth.” Brain and Language 162: 46–59.


Arco, Juan E, Carlos González-Garcı́a, Paloma Dı́az-Gutiérrez, Javier Ramı́rez, and Marı́a Ruz. 2018. “Influence of Activation Pattern Estimates and Statistical Significance Tests in fMRI Decoding Analysis.” Journal of Neuroscience Methods 308: 248–60.


Delaire, Édouard, Thomas Vincent, Zhengchen Cai, Alexis Machado, Laurent Hugueville, Denis Schwartz, Francois Tadel, et al. 2025. “NIRSTORM: A Brainstorm Extension Dedicated to Functional Near-Infrared Spectroscopy Data Analysis, Advanced 3D Reconstructions, and Optimal Probe Design.” Neurophotonics 12 (2): 025011–11.


Fabbri, Francesco, Angelo Sassaroli, Michael E Henry, and Sergio Fantini. 2004. “Optical Measurements of Absorption Changes in Two-Layered Diffusive Media.” Physics in Medicine & Biology 49 (7): 1183.


Fishburn, Frank A, Ruth S Ludlum, Chandan J Vaidya, and Andrei V Medvedev. 2019. “Temporal Derivative Distribution Repair (TDDR): A Motion Correction Method for fNIRS.” Neuroimage 184: 171–79.


Fu, Xiaoxue, and John E Richards. 2021. “devfOLD: A Toolbox for Designing Age-Specific fNIRS Channel Placement.” Neurophotonics 8 (4): 045003–3.


Gemignani, Jessica, and Judit Gervain. 2021. “Comparing Different Pre-Processing Routines for Infant fNIRS Data.” Developmental Cognitive Neuroscience 48: 100943.


Gramfort, Alexandre, Martin Luessi, Eric Larson, Denis A Engemann, Daniel Strohmeier, Christian Brodbeck, Roman Goj, et al. 2013. “MEG and EEG Data Analysis with MNE-Python.” Frontiers in Neuroinformatics 7: 267.


Huppert, Theodore J, Solomon G Diamond, Maria A Franceschini, and David A Boas. 2009. “HomER: a review of time-series analysis methods for near-infrared spectroscopy of the brain .” Appl Opt 48 (10): D280–98. https://doi.org/10.1364/ao.48.00d280.


Luke, Robert, Eric Larson, Maureen J Shader, Hamish Innes-Brown, Lindsey Van Yper, Adrian KC Lee, Paul F Sowman, and David McAlpine. 2021. “Analysis Methods for Measuring Passive Auditory fNIRS Responses Generated by a Block-Design Paradigm.” Neurophotonics 8 (2): 025008–8.


Pinti, Paola, Felix Scholkmann, Antonia Hamilton, Paul Burgess, and Ilias Tachtsidis. 2019. “Current Status and Issues Regarding Pre-Processing of fNIRS Neuroimaging Data: An Investigation of Diverse Signal Filtering Methods Within a General Linear Model Framework.” Frontiers in Human Neuroscience 12: 505.


Pollonini, Luca, Heather Bortfeld, and John S Oghalai. 2016. “PHOEBE: A Method for Real Time Mapping of Optodes-Scalp Coupling in Functional Near-Infrared Spectroscopy.” Biomedical Optics Express 7 (12): 5104–19.


Santosa, Hendrik, Xuetong Zhai, Frank Fishburn, and Theodore Huppert. 2018. “The NIRS Brain AnalyzIR Toolbox.” Algorithms 11 (5): 73.


Stute, Katharina, Louisa K Gossé, Samuel Montero-Hernandez, Guy A Perkins, Meryem A Yücel, Simone Cutini, Turgut Durduran, et al. 2025. “The fNIRS Glossary Project: A Consensus-Based Resource for Functional Near-Infrared Spectroscopy Terminology.” Neurophotonics 12 (2): 027801–1.


Tadel, François, Sylvain Baillet, John C Mosher, Dimitrios Pantazis, and Richard M Leahy. 2011. “Brainstorm: A User-Friendly Application for MEG/EEG Analysis.” Computational Intelligence and Neuroscience 2011 (1): 879716.


Yücel, Meryem Ayşe, Robert Luke, Rickson Coelho Mesquita, Alexander von Lühmann, David Marc Anton Mehler, Michael Lührs, Jessica Gemignani, et al. 2024. “The fNIRS Reproducibility Study Hub (FRESH): Exploring Variability and Enhancing Transparency in fNIRS Neuroimaging Research.”


Zimeo Morais, Guilherme Augusto, Joana Bisol Balardin, and João Ricardo Sato. 2018. “fNIRS Optodes’ Location Decider (fOLD): A Toolbox for Probe Arrangement Guided by Brain Regions-of-Interest.” Scientific Reports 8 (1): 3341.
